content: The "Physician Assistant Higher Education Modernization Act of 2017" increases annual loan limits for physician assistant students under the Federal Direct Loan Program. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to increase annual loan limits for physician assistant students in a Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loan program. The maximum amounts that can be borrowed per academic year are $40,000 in the first and second years, and $15,000 in the third year. The amendment will take effect for award years starting more than 60 days after the enactment of the Act. Physician assistants are now eligible for incentives when serving as primary care providers or faculty members. Physician assistants are now eligible for incentives when serving as primary care providers or faculty members, as per the recent amendment to the Higher Education Act of 1965. This includes working full-time in a clinical setting providing primary care services or as a member of the faculty at a physician assistant education program. Physician assistants eligible for incentives must be certified by the National Commission on the Certification of Physician Assistants, hold a valid license to practice in the state where they work, or be qualified for licensure if employed as full-time faculty in a physician assistant education program. The amendments made by this section, effective for employment after the enactment of this Act, update the fiscal year reference from 2009 to 2018 in the Public Health Service Act. Grants for physician assistant programs at historically black colleges and universities and predominantly black institutions. Grants for physician assistant programs at historically black colleges and universities are amended to include physician assistant studies in various subsections of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The education program under the Public Health Service Act is amended to include improving facilities for distance education technologies and collaborating with other institutions for postbaccalaureate degree offerings. Additionally, the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include physician assistant studies in historically black colleges and universities. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include physician assistant studies in historically black colleges and universities, as well as improving facilities for distance education technologies and collaborating with other institutions for postbaccalaureate degree offerings. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to extend authorization of appropriations for postbaccalaureate degree offerings until fiscal year 2018. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize physician assistant education programs for Hispanic Americans and extend authorization of appropriations until fiscal year 2018. SEC. 6. Grants to rural serving institutions of higher education for physician assistant education programs are supported under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary can award grants to rural-serving institutions of higher education to increase enrollment and graduation rates for physician assistant education programs in rural areas. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 3 years. Rural-serving institutions of higher education can apply for grants to create new physician assistant education programs in rural areas and increase the number of physician assistants practicing in rural areas. Priority is given to innovative approaches with the most potential. Rural-serving institutions of higher education can receive grants to establish and expand physician assistant education programs in rural areas, with a focus on meeting employment needs, improving health outcomes, and increasing the number of physician assistants practicing in rural areas. Grant funds must be used for the development of these programs. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal year 2018 and the following five years to support the establishment and expansion of physician assistant education programs in rural-serving institutions of higher education. SEC. 7. IMPROVING PHYSICIAN ASSISTANT EDUCATION PROGRAMS. A new section is added to Title VIII of the Higher Education Act of 1965, creating a demonstration program to support physician assistant faculty preparation. The Secretary will provide grants to up to 10 institutions of higher education to develop graduate-level programs for certified physician assistants to become faculty members. Each institution cannot receive more than $600,000 in total during fiscal years 2018-2020. Institutions must submit an application to the Secretary to be considered for the grant. The Secretary will provide grants to institutions for developing graduate-level programs to prepare certified physician assistants as faculty members. Applications must include a collaboration description and student estimate. Priority is given to applications using technology for quality instruction. A report to Congress is due 18 months after the first grant. The Secretary will provide grants to institutions for developing graduate-level programs to prepare certified physician assistants as faculty members. A report to Congress is required detailing implementation steps and listing grant recipients. Definitions for "institution of higher education" and "physician assistant education program" are provided. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2018 through 2020. Grants are provided for infrastructure and technology improvements in physician assistant education programs. The Secretary can award grants to up to 20 physician assistant education programs to enhance education and patient safety through new infrastructure and technology. Grants are awarded for a maximum of five years. Programs must apply by demonstrating how funds will be used for improvements. The Secretary prioritizes grants for physician assistant education programs that aim to increase graduates and improve accessibility to new technologies. Funds can be used for equipment purchase or lease, including human patient simulators. The section outlines the use of funds for educational purposes, including equipment purchase, maintenance of facilities, faculty training in new technologies, and other approved activities. The section authorizes appropriations for physician assistant education programs, defines a human patient simulator, and allocates funds for fiscal years 2018-2023.
